      • NETWORK_CHECK_INTERVAL

        public static final long NETWORK_CHECK_INTERVAL

      • MIN_DELAY_TO_USE_SCHEDULER_IN_MS

        public static final long MIN_DELAY_TO_USE_SCHEDULER_IN_MS
        The min delay in MS which will trigger usage of JobScheduler. If a job is added with a delay in less than this value, JobManager will not use the scheduler to wake up the application.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • JobManager

        public JobManager(Configuration configuration)
        Creates a JobManager with the given configuration
        Parameters:
        configuration - The configuration to be used for the JobManager
        See Also:
        Configuration.Builder

    • Method Detail

      • getScheduler

        public Scheduler getScheduler()
        The scheduler that was given to this JobManager when it was initialized.

        The scheduler is used by the JobService to communicate with the JobManager.

        Returns:
        The scheduler that was given to this JobManager or null if it does not exist

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the JobManager if it is not already running.
        See Also:
        stop()

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops the JobManager. Currently running Jobs will continue to run but no new Jobs will be run until restarted.
        See Also:
        start()

      • getActiveConsumerCount

        public int getActiveConsumerCount()
        Returns the number of consumer threads that are currently running Jobs. This number includes consumer threads that are currently idle.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        Returns:
        The number of consumer threads

      • destroy

        public void destroy()
        Destroys the JobManager. You cannot make any calls to this JobManager after this call. Useful to be called after your tests.
        See Also:
        stopAndWaitUntilConsumersAreFinished()

      • stopAndWaitUntilConsumersAreFinished

        public void stopAndWaitUntilConsumersAreFinished()
        Stops the JobManager and waits until all currently running Jobs are complete (or failed). Useful to be called in your tests.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        See Also:
        destroy()

      • waitUntilConsumersAreFinished

        public void waitUntilConsumersAreFinished()
        Waits until all consumers are destroyed. If min consumer count is NOT 0, this method will never return.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

      • addJobInBackground

        public void addJobInBackground(Job job)
        Adds a Job to the JobManager. This method instantly returns and does not wait until the Job is added. You should always prefer this method over addJob(Job).
        Parameters:
        job - The Job to be added
        See Also:
        addJobInBackground(Job, AsyncAddCallback), addJob(Job)

      • cancelJobsInBackground

        public void cancelJobsInBackground(CancelResult.AsyncCancelCallback cancelCallback,
                                   TagConstraint constraint,
                                   java.lang.String... tags)
        Cancels the Jobs that match the given criteria. If a Job that matches the criteria is currently running, JobManager waits until it finishes its Job.onRun() method before calling the callback.
        Parameters:
        cancelCallback - The callback to call once cancel is handled
        constraint - The constraint to be used to match tags
        tags - The list of tags

      • addCallback

        public void addCallback(JobManagerCallback callback)
        Adds a JobManagerCallback to observe this JobManager.
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be added

      • removeCallback

        public boolean removeCallback(JobManagerCallback callback)
        Removes the JobManagerCallback from the callbacks list. This method is safe to be called inside any method of the JobManagerCallback.
        Parameters:
        callback - The callback to be removed
        Returns:
        true if the callback is removed, false otherwise (if it did not exist).

      • addJob

        public void addJob(Job job)
        Adds the Job to the JobManager and waits until the add is handled.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time. Even if you are not on the main thread, you should prefer using addJobInBackground(Job) or addJobInBackground(Job, AsyncAddCallback) if you don't need to block your thread until the Job is actually added.

        Parameters:
        job - The Job to be added
        See Also:
        addJobInBackground(Job), addJobInBackground(Job, AsyncAddCallback)

      • addJobInBackground

        public void addJobInBackground(Job job,
                               AsyncAddCallback callback)
        Adds a Job in a background thread and calls the provided callback once the Job is added to the JobManager.
        Parameters:
        job - The Job to be added
        callback - The callback to be invoked once Job is saved in the JobManager's queues

      • cancelJobs

        public CancelResult cancelJobs(TagConstraint constraint,
                               java.lang.String... tags)
        Cancels jobs that match the given criteria. This method blocks until the cancellation is handled, which might be a long time if a Job that matches the given criteria is currently running. Consider using cancelJobsInBackground(CancelResult.AsyncCancelCallback, TagConstraint, String...) if possible.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        Parameters:
        constraint - The constraints to be used for tags
        tags - The list of tags
        Returns:
        A cancel result that has the list of cancelled and failed to cancel Jobs. A job might fail to cancel if it already started before cancel request is handled.

      • count

        public int count()
        Returns the number of jobs in the JobManager. This number does not include jobs that are currently running.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        Returns:
        The number of jobs that are waiting to be run

      • countReadyJobs

        public int countReadyJobs()
        Returns the number of jobs that are ready to be executed but waiting in the queue.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        Returns:
        The number of jobs that are ready to be executed but waiting in the queue.

      • getJobStatus

        public JobStatus getJobStatus(java.lang.String id)
        Returns the current status of a given job

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.

        Parameters:
        id - The id of the job (Job.getId())
        Returns:
        The current status of the Job

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clears all waiting Jobs in the JobManager. Note that this won't touch any job that is currently running.

        You cannot call this method on the main thread because it may potentially block it for a long time.
